paper_metadata.title: Modeling of Energy Consumption in Milling Process to Assess their Environmental Impact
paper_metadata.journal_or_conference: Master's Thesis, KTH Royal Institute of Technology

machine_info.machine_name: AFM Defum R1000 Three Axis Vertical Milling Center

spindle_air_cutting_power_w.description: Power consumed by the spindle when not engaged with the workpiece, dependent on spindle speed.

axis_movement_power_consumption.model_description: Linear models to predict power consumption based on feed rate (Vf).
axis_movement_power_consumption.note: Hysteresis was observed in the Y-axis power consumption, where forward feed consumed less power than reverse feed.

energy_data.measurement_method: Total machine power was measured with a Yokogawa WT500 power analyzer (1 Hz sampling rate). Spindle and axis power were recorded independently using the Siemens Sinumerik 828D's Trace function (0.003s sampling rate for active power).

environmental_impact_contribution.solid_end_mill_finding: The consumption of solid cemented carbide end mills is the dominant source of environmental impact, contributing 98% to 99% of the total.
environmental_impact_contribution.inserted_cutter_simulation: A simulation using inserted cutters showed a more balanced contribution, with the cutters accounting for 54% and electricity for 46% of the impact.

mitigation_strategies.summary: The study suggests that the most viable strategies for mitigating the environmental impact in the studied milling processes involve the cutting tools rather than electricity consumption.
strategies: Using reconditioned tools to reduce the need for manufacturing new ones
Employing inserted cutters, which only require replacing the cutting edge instead of the entire tool
Selecting smaller tools when possible, as a comparison showed a 10mm end mill had a lower g CO2-eq/FU than a 12mm one for the same MRR.

additional_notes: This thesis presents a framework to model energy consumption and assess the environmental impact of dry milling processes using a simplified experimental approach based on mechanistic modeling principles. A key finding is that for dry milling with solid tools, the environmental impact is dominated by the tool's lifecycle emissions, not the electricity consumed during the process. The proposed prediction model demonstrated good accuracy, though it tends to underestimate cutting power due to factors like unmodeled efficiency losses and tool wear.
